- Shishmaref, Alaska is a
small Inupiat village just
south of the Arctic Circle.
The winter sun is scarce.

And when it rises, the
place is frozen in twilight.
It's a harsh, cold environment--

a community that
survives on ice.

ESAU SINNOK: We need the ice to
go out and hunt for our seals,
to get our fish.

And we rely so much off
the land and the sea.

- Esau Sinnok is 19, and grew
up on this barrier island.

His parents raise huskies for
sledding and harvest chunks
of ice for drinking water.

Today, they pulled
tomcod from a lagoon.

The water froze weeks
later than normal--

the surface just
thick enough to fish.

The Inupiat people have lived
here for at least 400 years.

But now, Esau and his
family's greatest fears
are being realized.

It looks like this community
won't last much longer.
The culprit-- climate change.

Scientists say the Arctic is
heating up more than twice as
fast as the rest of the planet.

What would be the future of this
island if people don't move?

ESAU SINNOK: Then we're
going to be underwater, John.
Yeah.
This island is done.

- A trip here then it's like a
trip into a disturbing future.

After one of the big storms,
almost all of your neighbors
left.

This is Esau's grandfather,
Shelton Kokeof.

He lives with his wife,
Clara, in a tiny blue house
at the edge of the Earth.

It's a location that's
newly precarious.

As temperatures rise,
the ocean is freezing
later and thawing earlier.

That makes the land more
susceptible to erosion.

Sea walls attempt to
hold the island in place,

but big chunks of earth
have fallen into the sea.

The island is
slowly disappearing.

This is where the coast
was expected to be in 2013.

And here's where it's expected
to be by about mid century.

Shelton worries his house
could fall off the edge.

That kind of thing
has happened before.
Tell me about that picture.
Like, what is that?
And what happened?

ANNIE WEYIOUANNA: That
picture is my husband's house
that he grew up in.
Now, it's in the ocean.

If you went down that way today,
or recently, it's not there.

- Annie Weyiouanna is a local
official in Shishmaref, which
has a population of about 560.

And because of these dramatic
changes, she and this village

are faced with an
almost unthinkable task.

They're planning to move
to a safer location.

Last summer, during the
hottest year on record,

residents voted 89
to 78 to relocate
because of extreme warming.

But without funding,
this village is stuck.

ANNIE WEYIOUANNA: We don't have
the millions and millions of
dollars in our pocket to move.
If you have that, give it up.
We'd like it.
- It's not just Shishmaref.

According to a 2009
government report,

more than 30 Alaska
villages are immediately

threatened by
erosion and flooding
linked to climate change.

And 12 of them are said to be
exploring relocation options.

And this isn't
just Alaska either.

As oceans warm and
ice melts, sea levels
are rising worldwide.

Miami, Shanghai,
New York all will
be threatened with flooding.

A town in the
Louisiana bayou already

has watched its land disappear,
in part because of dams
that blocked vital sediment.

But now, climate
change is threatening
to make things even worse.

And last year, a local
tribe got a $48 million
grant to relocate.

It's unclear if Shishmaref will
be able to get similar funds.

ESAU SINNOK: Climate
change refugees

are what we're going to become
in the next few decades.

- Some elders including, Esau's
grandparents, want to stay.

But Esau thinks this
community has no choice.

In January, arctic sea
ice was at a record low.

And temperatures
in the region have

been soaring to 20 degrees
above average in early February.

He says the only way to
survive is to get out.

ESAU SINNOK: If
you ask the older

generations, like
my grandfather,

their views are
totally different.

They want to stay on this
island forever and ever.

But to me, I think
we have to relocate,

so that our future generations
can still be alive.

- Climate change
and relocation have
become deeply personal for him.

Esau's Uncle Norman, Shelton's
son, fell through the ice

and died on a
hunting trip in 2007.

Elders say the ice where
he died should have
been frozen that time of year.

Esau believes that
climate change played
a role in his uncle's death.

ESAU SINNOK: There's
not a day that goes
by that I do not think of him.
He's always on my mind.
He's always in my heart.

- The death propelled
Esau into advocacy.

Now, he's an ambassador
for youth in the Arctic,

getting recognized by
the Obama White House

and attending international
climate negotiations in Paris.

ESAU SINNOK: I
really loved that,
because I get to tell my story.

I get to tell that
climate change is real.

- It's a subject that's
difficult, but he's not bitter.

ESAU SINNOK: I don't
blame it on one
person or a group of people.

It's all our fault.
It's not 1940s anymore.

We can use fossil fuels
anymore to heat our homes,
use for our energy.

We can transition from
dirty fossil fuels
to renewable energies.

- And as for those who deny
the science of climate change,
Esau offers them an invitation.
Come to Shishmaref, he says.

Up here, the facts
are undeniable.
